text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single full‐page miniature contained within a four‐line fillet border, no accompanying text, image occupies entire visual field with decorative frame

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf highlights fleur-de-lis patterns, crown and liturgical objects, signifying royal and ecclesiastical authority. Ultramarine blue dominates garments and background, denoting high status. Vermilion red defines curtained niche and occasional dress accents. White lead used sparingly for highlights on folds. Layered application of gold over gesso creates slight relief. Overall palette is well preserved with minimal pigment degradation.

features: Linear grouping of figures along a horizontal axis
Dominant diagonal from bishop’s hand to kneeling noble
Overlapping figures to suggest spatial depth
Enclosed curtained niche framing main action

decorative_elements: Fillet border with gilt corner motifs
Cloisonné-like geometric background of blue and gold roundels
Gothic micro-architecture canopy with carved saints
Fleur-de-lis motif repeated on garments and crown

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine quill‐pen outlines with consistent line weight, subtle internal flourishes in drapery
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal parallel hatching in drapery folds, white lead highlights to model volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling, overlapping figures, pseudo‐perspective via tiled floor, no true linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: In a single scene, a mitred bishop in a blue, fleur-de-lis-patterned cope stands on a dais before a curtained Gothic canopy bearing carved saints. He extends a gilded ring-like object or anointment implement toward a kneeling noble draped in a matching blue, fleur-de-lis robe, hands clasped in supplication. To the left, four attendants—two in identical fleur-de-lis mantles, one bearing an open crown decorated with trefoil fleur-de-lis and the other a sword with gold pommel—stand in graduated order, two additional courtiers behind them. The floor is laid out in a red-and-white diamond tile pattern that recedes to suggest space. The tiled dais lifts the bishop and supplicant above the attendants. Costume details include the bishop’s white alb, gold-stitched stole and ornate mitre inscribed with fine penwork; the noble’s robe has a visible weave pattern indicated by light brush strokes. The crown features detailed punchwork on its circlet rim, and the sword has a jewelled pommel. The red damask curtains, patterned dais cloth and blue-gold background create a rich visual hierarchy that centers the investiture act. Decorative border fillets frame the scene, underscoring its ceremonial import.

religious: Bishop wearing mitre, cope and alb, holding a gilded liturgical implement
secular: Kneeling nobleman in blue fleur-de-lis robe
Two additional courtiers in fleur-de-lis mantles

objects: Gilded open crown with fleur-de-lis trefoils
Sword with gold pommel and cruciform hilt
architectural: Gothic micro-architecture canopy with carved saints

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, smooth burnished flesh side with visible hair-follicle pattern, ruled lightly in plummet for miniature layout
technical_features.preservation_condition: Pigments vivid and stable, slight flaking in red areas, minimal cockling at folio edges, evidence of modern consolidation in lower margin
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso ground beneath gold leaf motifs
Fine underdrawing visible under UV illumination
Layered brush strokes in drapery folds
Regular ruling pattern evident on verso

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Courtly or noble patron consulting a commissioned chronicle

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This miniature likely originates from a late 14th-century French court workshop, perhaps associated with the production of lavish chronicles such as those by Jean Froissart. The exclusive use of ultramarine and burnished gold, together with the fleur-de-lis motif, signals royal patronage—perhaps commemorating the investiture of a high noble or a royal appointee by an ecclesiastical authority. The artist’s confident quill-pen underdrawing and the refined gesso relief beneath the gold demonstrate the technical sophistication of Parisian illuminators. The composition’s hierarchical scaling—placing the bishop and kneeling noble on a raised dais—reinforces the sanctified nature of the investiture act, while the red damask curtains and patterned floor tiles evoke an intimate, yet sumptuous, courtly interior. Iconographically, the scene marries ecclesiastical and feudal power: the mitred prelate confers symbols of temporal authority, thus visually asserting the church’s legitimizing role in monarchical politics. Comparatively, this scene shares stylistic affinities with the Grandes Chroniques of Charles V, notably in its jewel-like color palette and architectural framing. The miniature both upholds traditional iconographic programs of investiture and innovates through its unified decorative background and subtle modeling of figures, situating it at the confluence of Gothic tradition and emerging naturalism within high medieval illumination.
